intro: Symphoricarpos oreophilus var. parishii, commonly known as the Sierra buffaloberry, is a shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the heather family (Ericaceae) and is characterized by its dense, thorny stems and clusters of small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces bright red, fleshy berries that are an important food source for wildlife. It thrives in moist, acidic soils and is often found in mountainous regions. Its botanical features make it well adapted to high-altitude environments with cool, temperate climates.
